episode.title: Interstate Circuit, Inc. v. City of Dallas

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: -- to wind up and go into Court all the time.

These litigants do not have big pockets to pay expenses and so you have the proposition which would affect Mr. Nizer's case more than mine but if the local exhibitor owed in contest within the pictures classified and would there have to bear the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: -- marketing.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think the non-contesting part of it should come after when a complaint is filed in the Court?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think as soon as --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Like every -- every picture classified is none suitable -- it's not suitable for young children should have a complaint filed on it in a court?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: If the -- yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And a -- and a default judgment entered?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: No sir.
The default judgment certainly should be taken but that leaves again free speech unprotected because a man takes one of these pictures and has a limited license a small fee --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- then would you prefer some mechanism by -- Court and have a judgment entered that you could keep it out of Court?
Wouldn't you like some proceeding like that?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: That is one that Mr. Nizer --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What seems to be what you're complaining about is some --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: No sir, what I'm complaining about if I may say is this that they talked about Freedman and they changed their position on Freedman.
Freedman's overall burden mentioned that prior Maryland case, that's the real thrust of this argument.

There, it mentioned Maryland versus United Artist and Board of Censors in 1956 and it admit -- it pointed out that the risk of delay was built into the only reported case in Maryland because it took six months from trial to final decision.
Now, six months was what mistaken there, the record of Viva Maria is eight-and-a-half months.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean from the time of the adminis -- at the beginning of the administrative proceeding?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Suit was filed in a Maryland Censor case on February 28th and July 13th.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, now I'm talking about Texas --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: My case was eight-and-a-half months.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that appears through the -- that appears through the Supreme Court of Texas.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, Justice.
The final judicial determination, if the Court please, in Texas.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, and what's your Freedman means then?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What was it -- the interval from the time this picture was filed with this Board until the February 18th date when the trial court entered its judgment was how many days.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: February 18th, the picture was filed with the Board on the 9th of February, I believe.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So that's nine days then from the time of filing with the Board until the trial court determination?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, forgetting the other aspects on which you challenged --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- the Court, as a time interval, do you think that would come within Freedman in nine days?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, I would say, it would be close enough, I wouldn't argue.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
So, on the time then your real complain I gather is that it then took upwards to better than eight months --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- before the appellate process was completed.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, do you find anything in Freedman that purports to say the states that they must so order their appellate processes as to give appellate review in these cases on a priority basis?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: I would think so, if the Court please.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Was there any thing in Freedman that says that?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: I would think so.
Toward the end of the opinion, this Court did not only used words idly --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I used it

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: -- and I understand that.
But from final, the word “final” that came in here was expelled out.
Also, the opinion states to avoid the danger of an interim and possibly erroneous denial of a license.
Now, an interim is possibly erroneous denial of a license is exactly what may have happened to us here in Judge Taft's decision at the trial level.
But this term final judicial determination was understood by Maryland to advance and require an amendment of its statute which is done, that's reported in Trans-Lux that is cited in my brief.
Now, --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what if --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: If I may --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- would you say that -- could the Texas just say there will be no appeals at all under these cases from the trial court decision?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well, they could but we have the unique situation, Your Honor.
The legislature was in session in 1967, when Freedman came out, they did nothing.
But in 1967, they were in session again and on page 17 of my brief we have been managing general insurance agent site.
And that thing gives the priority to an insurance salesman's license.
The likes of which the First Amendment should get, it goes to the first docket at the trial court, the Court of Civil Appeals and the Supreme Court of Texas --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm just wondering --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: -- I mean, no worries (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If there is another -- if there isn't another problem involved here, on what can depend any order of this Court to the states that they must so order their appellate procedures in their highest courts as to determine appellate review in these cases before they determine anything else, capital cases or other cases that --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- how do we do that?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: -- I think it can leave Freedman as it was.
The Court there said it was not spending out the exact time but the spirit of Freedman was a prompt final judicial determination.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And why does the City Council of Dallas doesn't have any power whatsoever to tell the Supreme Court of Texas --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- as that you lack in any case, does it?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: The exactly true if the Court please.

But if the State of Texas is what said about in Freedman and then Maryland how or whether Maryland is to incorporate the required procedural safeguards in the statutory scheme is of course for the State of Maryland to decide.
That's exactly true for Texas if they won't to avail themselves this.
The legislature could give these cases the priority equivalent to what it gave to the insurance agent.
That's all we're asking for from this -- when state policy gives the priority an insurance agent's license and it literally gives to the head of everything throughout the state.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of course the Freedman case involved, did it not, the denial of a license to exhibit the movie?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This case is not at all, is it?
(Voice Overlap) exhibit this movie and play it everyday for six months in Dallas ground out your projectors 24 hours a day as far as I know if you just put on it not suitable for children.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if you put on it not suitable for children and we define a young person and define what they are in the broad principle as I mentioned earlier if the Court please.
In the broad principle, what is the difference between not suitable for 18 and not suitable for 16?
If I were to judge by standard or ask anyone else to how would I sensibly measure a difference and consider this book would pass for 18 but this book would not pass for 16.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, there's some arbitrary about every age limit, how much differences there in voting between somebody who's 20 years and 11 months and 29 days and somebody who has a day older and yet that makes a four-year difference and when he can vote in a presidential election.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: That is true if the Court please.
I certainly agree with that but we're not called upon as we understand this is so restricted because --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And this Court has never held that there was anything wrong about that 18-year-old evidence as ordinance, has it?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: No.
They may --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I don't quite see the relevance of your question, your hypothetical question.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the relevance --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In between in 18 and a 16-year-old cut off date.
This Court has never held that there's anything wrong with the 18.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: We say that relevance is this, if the Court please, we come to a relevant item because the City of Dallas set out to come under your clear-and-present-danger doctrine for 18 year olds, and obviously people who would be in a juvenile crime group would be at the senior part of this, they fell away from the 18 standard and went to 16.
16 is a little more appealing, but if we sustain this preset which they're holding for here, then we can immediately find 18, 19, or whatever age on up unto 21.

In the broad principle until there is some showing, we submit that it is time for -- enough to prove this before and to prove for example if there is such proof that this causes this crime way where there are some reason for restraint, but until that is done a presumption in favor of free speech.
That's what we're asking.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, of course the First Amendment, I suppose, philosophically you would agree depends and grows from the concept of free choice.
Anybody is free to say or print what he wants and anybody is free to listen or to read what he wants.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And free choice, I suppose, is that philosophy is on the premise of the capacity to make free choice to make choices.
And I suppose you and I would both agree that a child of 18 months doesn't have that capacity, wouldn't he?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Certainly sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So there must be some period at which the First Amendment is no longer --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- so long this (Voice Overlap) of you argument?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: -- we, I did not come here arguing an 18-year-old child that has the right to go to the picture show by himself very obviously but I wouldn't say --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Hartt, wouldn't you think that an 18-year-old GI from Saigon that not be corrupted by a movie.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: I would certainly concur in that opinion, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It could not be the reason it got --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Couldn't that be the reason they got from --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: That is certainly one of the big reasons obviously.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: I mean --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- in this question of time, do you take the position that the State of Texas in order to uphold this ordinance must get precedent to your case over a speedy trial in Murdock?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.
In the sense, I would say --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well, for this simple reason.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think I read somebody's speedy trial in a certain constitution?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir and I read that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: This is not in the Constitution

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: I read -- I have read that that is if I understand it correctly that concept is written into a prompt final judicial determination here.
Now, I must say Mr.--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What is the final judicial determination?
Didn't you get a final judgment in the trial court?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: We'll, we've got a judgment --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) the final judgment?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: But that is not the final judgment as we understand --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What's your final judgment?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: It was an appealable judgment, in that sense, the final, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And it had to be final.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: It was final in that sense.

But at the same time, when they spoke of the appellate judgment in the Maryland case of 1956, if the Court please, we understood that to mean both trial and appellate when they have said six months for trial in appellate --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But in today, isn't it an eight-month determination by the highest court of the states speedy?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: I would think it is tremendous if the Court please.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This is final then either then in your term, is it?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think that Freedman given a reason and interpretation means that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how can you cut it off the State Supreme Court if you're going to cut the appellate process?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: You don't cut it off there, but you have to review there.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know but you aren't through yet.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You're up here now.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: That is true.
But the determination --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, may I ask this Mr. Hartt?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Let's see how this -- what your approach concretely is.
Obviously, the City of Dallas could not include in any ordinance, I gather, these municipal ordinances.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir, it does not have --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And it could not have a provision that any appellate review must be within X number of months.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It couldn't be done that.
So what you're saying, I gather, is that this ordinance we should say must be inoperative, however otherwise, it maybe constitutional.
It must be declared completely inoperative unless and until the legislature of the State of Texas --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- says that any judgment under this ordinance must be reviewed and finally determined by the Supreme Court of Texas within some specified period.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Reasonable time.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, anyway isn't that a difference in good sense between the way one would look at Freedman in terms of a total suppression or something, in a way one would look at Freedman in terms of an ordinance.
It says that children can't be allowed to view this.
Isn't there qualitative difference there?
Even if you assume, isn't it conceivable that you could have an arrangement that might offend Freedman if it were total suppression do you see?
In one hand, but would not offend Freedman if it were suppression that was confined to excluding children?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, I frankly don't think that you can consistently do it.
I personally don't know.
Well let's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose this ordinance --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: I beg your pardon, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose this ordinance that you provided instead of the effect that it does, it's something that deals, no parent in Texas should carry his son who is 20-and-a-half years old to see a picture that a Board in Dallas thinks is bad, what would you say about that law as to the rights of the father?
Could he be convicted criminally by taking his boy to that theatre?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I think he could be under that kind of an ordinance or statute, yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, do you say again it's a valid ordinance?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You would think that's a valid ordinance?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: No.
I say -- excuse me, I understood -- can he be convicted, I thought you asked me, yes he could be convicted unless you're going to follow and say that free speech is going to prevail.
The ordinance I think has got to fall on the first --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But another thing comes in mind, it's the right of the parent for the children and the right to the government for the children.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: And also the rights of the children as the Gault case --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but this ordinance allows even as to this part -- this motion picture, as I understand it there's any provision in this ordinance that one under 16 may see the picture if taken to the picture by parent, guardian, wife, or spouse or something?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: 16 year olds who are married can go?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.
That's the normal exception but your --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know.
But addressed to Mr. Justice Black's question --

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- this ordinance or am I wrong about that?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: The technical reading of this ordinance as pointed out by Mr. Nizer yesterday makes that an affirmative defense only.
We have never --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In a prosecution?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: We have never gotten around to that part --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Or any other proceeding whatever that means?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, that's where we were, yesterday.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose this 20-and-a-half year old man happen to be married?

turn.speaker: grover_hartt
turn.label: Mr. Grover Hartt, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if he had his wife with him --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think his wife would be considerate?
And she said all the words through the picture, Your Honor, I think that would be a defense.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Bickley.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice Warren and Associate Justices, may I address myself to the latest question that was just raised.
This is about the right of the parent and the right of children.

This ordinance does provide, as we read it and as we interpret it and as the city council passed, that a parent, a guardian, a husband, or wife may take a child or a young person below the age of 16 years to a movie that is designated as not acceptable for young persons.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It provides that now?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It provides that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It has the right to provide that they may take their children, why does a man have a right to provide that they shall not take their children?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, I believe Mr. Nizer stated yesterday that in his opinion they did have that right maybe to prohibit any of them from going any used as an example of pool halls which he likened to the right of assembly and he said you could prevent young persons from assembling in a pool hall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You said, you could prevent them from attending any movie.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes, he said that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Because you couldn't pick and choose the movie --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: But you could not --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- that he can see?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- pick and choose, this is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's what I understood you say.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Alright, yes, and I -- this is what I'd like to address myself to.He said but he likened it to the pool halls but he said that he would not accept the pool hall analogy because of the fact that this was based upon safety of the young person.
Now, it is with this argument that I would take disagreement because of the fact that preventing young persons from going in a pool hall is not a safety provision.
There is no danger of falling off a pool table or being injured in the pool hall.
It's the immorality that this is actually directed to because the YMCA's have pools in many cities and allow individuals to play young persons, to participate but under certain conditions.

Now, insofar as that applies here as to whether or not you can pick and choose, we think that actually it would be more unconstitutional not to pick and choose and it would to pick and choose for this simple reason, to prevent young persons under the age of 16 years from attending any movie would be the most blatant sort of the restriction on the freedom of speech.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Bickley, what's wrong with this picture?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Justice --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Have you seen it by the way?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Have you seen it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I have seen the picture, yes sir on two or three different occasions.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What's wrong with it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall, let me say this about this picture, it is a marginal picture.
I must admit this to this Court and I'll be very frank in this respect.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what is on the other side of the margin?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: As was pointed out by Reverend Masio (ph) and I agree with him in this respect, it depicts sexual promiscuity in this manner.

It shows a woman who goes and under the influence of alcohol meets three men for the first time in an evening and goes and has an evening with them on all evening escapade which is not shown, comes back in the morning with their closed pool half way off and they shout.
And she comes back and she says, “This is the life or this is the fun I have been missing”.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What's wrong with that?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, maybe -- for some maybe it's not wrong, Mr. Chief Justice -- Mr. Justice Marshall but --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But for example --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I apologize.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- is it obscene?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I apologize.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is it obscene?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No sir.
It is not obscene.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what is it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It is implanting in the minds of the young people the thought to see the play that immorality of this sort -- of this kind --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is fun?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- is fun and the highest form of life.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I thought you said it was marginal --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- and desirable, and useful.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I thought you said it was marginal.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I say it is marginal, yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And is it your -- is it the position of the City of Dallas that you can apply this statute in what you style marginal situations of this ordinance -- on what you style marginal situations?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Justice Fortas, we would prefer not to apply them the marginal situation.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I know, I'm not asking --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- what you prefer doing.
I'm asking you whether it's your position that under this ordinance the prohibitions of this ordinance maybe applied in marginal situations.
Remember, they were talking about the First Amendment of the Constitution --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I understand that and --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- of the United States.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- and this is the reason I hope to answer very carefully --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- on this.
It is hard to determine sometimes and I think in cases of doubt --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Well, it's fairly easy to supply before decision that sounds marginal.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I suppose you to say that as far as the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It was an eight to one decision.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Eight to one?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Federal Constitution is concerned, marginal situation is exactly the kind of thing that both parties supposed to deal with.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, marginal situations are the ones that make lawsuits and that's the reason we're before this Court.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) Federal Constitution of the United States is not before this Court or the Board of Censorship and how we felt, but we're talking about the Constitution of the United States --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's exactly right sir.
That's exactly right.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But there are nine -- there are nine censors down there, there in Dallas?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Only nine?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: They are not censors --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: No?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- as we refer to them Your Honor but members of the Classification Board.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But five -- five to four decision would ban one of these movies?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It would actually do so.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It would not ban it sir.
It would not prohibit it.
It merely requires a label in the advertising.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: I understand.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's your answer to my question?
I say that's your answer to my question?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mu anwer to your question, Your Honor, is we do not prohibit anything.

We merely say, let's have it's somewhat near the truth in advertising sort of situation, it's somewhat near the situation of pick and choose if you will but give them something from which to pick and choose.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I'm asking you the following --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So, let us assume that this Board said to the city attorney or whoever its counsel is, we believe that this motion picture is marginal for purposes of application of this ordinance, for purposes of application of this ordinance.
In view of our conclusion that this is marginal, is it alright for us to go again and apply the ordinance to this picture?
I'm asking that --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: In --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- our view --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- as a matter of law.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: May a city attorney and may I answer you sir in an example which is a true example on the occasions in which I have before this Board actually fought with them and told them what this Court has held and what we think because of marginal situations they could not do and should not do and they have agreed to that and they have many instances, done things they did not want to do.

Personally, they disagreed with for this reason and we take this thing very seriously and for that reason we have attempted, it is true, we've got a situation here that may make some bad law because it is the marginal case.

But we have attempted to counsel with the Board and to work with them as officers of the Court and attempt to protect these First Amendment freedoms as best as we can but at the same time giving to the state the right to protect its young persons, if we can do that.
And we think that maybe this --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But particularly, in terms of the provisions of this ordinance, in terms of what it's aimed that preventing young people from seeing the way you describe the scene doesn't sound marginal in terms of the ordinance.
The ordinance supposedly attempts to keep young people from seeing precisely the kinds of things that you have said has earned this picture.
Now, what's marginal?
What so marginal about -- about these pictures because there's only one scene in the whole picture?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No.
No, because there are only a very few scenes in the whole picture.
Another one of the scenes that I did not described, Your Honor, was one that occurred inside the -- inside the jail --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: With the prisoners?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: One or two more.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is this ordinance -- this ordinance, the way it's been applied or does it say on its face that a picture may be classified this way if it's in whole or in part.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It says in whole taken as a whole, using the test that has been set out by this Court, that it must be considered as a whole.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If the picture -- if this picture were had a -- just a repetitious, just a whole of a lot of these sort of thing that you've been telling us about, you wouldn't think it would be marginal now?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, I would not think it was marginal if it -- if this was the whole theme of the movie as such.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But here you mean it's marginal only in the sense that applying the standard that's taken as a whole, these few incidents may not completely colored as -- as would perhaps whole series of it.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: This is right Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And it -- it may -- the standards are hard to apply as the obscenity standard is hard to apply, none of these are easy as counsel admit -- and if they're hard to draw, they're hard to define, and for this reason it does make for a hard --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But in terms of the quality of this scene, you think it's the kind of thing the ordinance does? But thoroughly is the kind of a thing the ordinance was attempting to reach?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Justice, if you say thoroughly, the kind of thing it was entitled to --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well I mean -- let's say it's -- it's not a marginal?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: If it were not marginal I think this is one of the things that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What happens if the scene itself in terms of quality or its content is not marginal?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, the scene by itself is not.
The movie as a whole is.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is the reason that the Board did not make any findings, the reason that the Board relied on as a whole phase?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes, the Board --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's correct, am I not?
The Board did not give any reasons.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct, they did not.
They did not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But do they ever?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, they do not write down the reasons for which they do it, Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: They --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: --how can the distributor or United Artist or this Court know the reason?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: For which they actually did it?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor before this Court will be confronted with that situation it must be proven before a judicial body.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And the decision will have to be made there.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I understand only two members of the Board testified.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Or do we know now the reason that the other six voted?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It is not in the record, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, is there any way for us to know?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I can advise you, but this is the only way.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But that would be hearsay rule, isn't it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That would be hearsay rule.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes, it would be hearsay.
It would be hearsay.
And I say for that reason it's not in the record and it does not show.
But this is the immaterial to a situation like this because of the fact that judge has to make a decision on a trial de novo.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But he gave no reasons either, did he?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: He gave no reasons at that particular time.
No he did not accept (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Isn't this the case where the judge brought in from some outlying county?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The judge came in from an outlying county.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And then --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And he's the one who said, “I've got too much work back at my -- back at home to be fussing around with this, it's enough and let it go”, wasn't that it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, that's not quite it, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The record certainly reads like that, they tried very hard to get them the status -- to make some findings of fact then he refused to make any.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct, (Voice Overlap) he refused to make findings of fact as such and he did not make them.
He did view the movie.
He did listen to the testimony.
He did listen to argument of counsel and he did then make a decision that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: When he had the standards of the statute before him?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: He had the standards of a statute, he had briefs of counsel, he had all of the consideration that counsel could give him and all of the advice and the argument that either of us could give to him at that time.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, here's what he said, “I decline when I asked.
I have so many irons for little fellow.
I have taken on more than I can do trying to decide a big case here and I've got others at home and here and then Hill County where I have been helping out.
I don't have the time to do it, I decline.”
That's what he said.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's exactly what he said Your Honor.
But we had been arguing with him for quite some time before he said this, and had been presenting ideas back and forth very freely.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, is this -- is this the one then?
“I realize you gentlemen might be right”, I guess he was talking to interstate counsel.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes, he was.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: “There are two or three features in this picture that look to me would be unsuitable to young people, actually they have tried to track that Freedman case looks like in this ordinance and if any ordinance can be passed where it looks like they have taken every ground to pass whether one can be valid, this is valid”.
That's what it was.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, I think he tried to follow the law as best he could understand it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There is something to what you say.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think anybody can understand it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes.
Sir, I'm -- I'm not really sure of what the understanding is when we get in these nebulous fields, they're hard, and they are difficult.
And so we are all trying to approach that thing which gives the rights of both parties proper precedent.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Can you tell me (Voice Overlap) how many movies have come to this Board a year (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir.
Between January 14th of 1966 and January 10th of 1968, there were 1925 movies submitted to the Board.
Of that number, 565 of them were classified as not suitable by the exhibitor himself.
He asked for that classification to be put on.

39 were classified as not suitable after screening by the Board itself and of the movies classified suitable, 1226 of them were classified suitable as submitted by the exhibitor and 59 of them were classified suitable after screening by the Committee and by the Classification Board.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Are those figures in your brief?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Those figures are not in the brief sir.
Those figures are just of recent vantage.
They -- actually we got those on January 10th, 1968.
We would like to submit them to the Court for their consideration in the record.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you have any idea in your experience and observation with the Board, how many would've been held bad?
And hadn't been for lawyers like you to tell them this Court, there, in the First Amendment protected a lot of large motion pictures, do you think it would have been anything like a smaller number?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr.--

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If you just left them (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, I'd hate to speculate with you on that particular statement, I do not know.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The Board was never on a position to tell this Court in passing the statute.
This is the first time spent -- this is the first time that we ever had it.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: This is the first time we've ever had an ordinance similar to this.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) as to what the attitude of this Court would be, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Not as to this.
We --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, let me --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- discussed very frankly --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let me correct you (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I didn't place that question, as to what you had told them about --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I understand sir.
I understand.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I understand.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What I see, have you not been warned that as a First Amendment which does protect certain kinds of pictures, can you prophesize how many more they would have barred than those they have already barred?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: May I answer it this way, Mr. Justice Black.
I could no more predict than I could predict without benefit of counsel how much smut and other type of things would be introduced into our system because it's a two-way proposition.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I accept your answer but I am sure that you can hold and it would have been a lot more, I heard your statement about what you had told them from time to time in your argument but -- how about the Constitution?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It's possible there would've been more sir, it's possible.
Insofar as the speedy remedy is concerned and the final judicial determination is concerned which was being discussed just a minute ago, I'd like to discuss it in a minute.

In these words, a careful reading of the ordinance of the City of Dallas will I think convince this Court of the very onerous burden that the city accepted upon itself in order that it might provide every remedy known and every opportunity for a speedy trial and speedy judicial determination.

Now, if final judicial determination as used in the Freedman case means by the highest court of the land and without appeal, then this body itself is the one the must give precedents to all these cases because this is the final bargain.
And so I think the case certainly did not mean that.
We get a final judgment before that trial court.
We get a judgment that is final and can be appealed from.
And that is a judicial determination.
Now, as to whether or not it's unconstitutional to require the movie industry, the exhibitors, as such to file a notice of nonacceptance before we go before that judicial tribunal.
I think this Court would not put upon us the burden of doing a vain fame because the movie industry itself does not walk the default judgment before the Court which --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- says they tried --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- I think Mr. Bickley, don't you, that that requirement of filing of notice of nonacceptance is surely inconsistent with some of the things said in the Freedman case.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Said in what?
In the Freedman?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In Freedman.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: In the Freedman case?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, isn't it?
Or is it inconsistent with the emphasis that Freedman gave to the burden being upon the government to proceed to the initial determination by a judge?
Because as I understand it, the way this works if whoever suppose to file the -- and it's definitely -- who may file a notice of nonacceptance besides the exhibitor?
Is it only the chap who submits the picture for classification?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, it maybe filed any exhibitor by any city.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Any exhibitor?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: In the city.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In a city?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But would this then --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- United Artist could not file?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Or United Artist -- the ordinance does not say that United Artist might do so.
We would assume that since they have a financial --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I know but --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- interest in the picture that they could do so, yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No.
Oh!
You assume it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Oh, yes.
We would accept that as a nonacceptance.
But the ordinance doesn't say this, does it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The ordinance does not actually say that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or it doesn't say it can't either, does it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It does not say it cannot because the only mode of speech from -- with United Artist in the City of Dallas is through its exhibitor relationship.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But the ordinance makes the failure to file the notice of nonacceptance that makes them, what do you call this Board, Classification Board?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Classification Board.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Determination, final doesn't it?
Never again subject to judicial review anywhere?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes it is.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: How?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It is again subject to judicial review if a subsequent exhibitor wants to show the same film and without the classification, he may again submit it to the Board for review and then file his notice of nonacceptance and have it tried by the Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's if there is another exhibitor, but suppose there isn't any.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The same exhibitor may do it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You mean --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: If he fails to file his notice of nonacceptance --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He may then resubmit --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- he can come in for a review.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You mean he can resubmit the picture?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: He can resubmit.
(Voice Overlap) He has given that right under the ordinance, if he so desires.
We have tried countless things with every precaution possible in a field like this.
Now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose he just go to him and shows the picture and doesn't submit to the Board?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: If he goes ahead and shows the picture without submitting it to the Board, then under our view of the case --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Under the law?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Under the law, under the ordinance, he has committed a misdemeanor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Committed a crime if he doesn't submit the picture for this Board to look at?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: If he shows it without submitting it, that's correct sir.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you say that's not censorship?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No sir, we do not think that's censorship.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I understood the charge to be made if he did.
I -- I couldn't quite understand it.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, no we don't think that's censorship, Your Honor (Voice Overlap), we actually -- actually, this was the same question that was in the Times Film case (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, whether you call it censorship or not, certainly in Freedman, we have sustained the constitutionality of procedures like is not violating the First Amendment, as long as the procedures we specified in Freedman are followed, haven't we?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And as long --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It doesn't matter whether you call it -- so I think myself for this censorship where it's a kind that --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Allowable censorship maybe sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Alright, that's what Freedman held, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes.
So maybe I'm wrong in saying (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let's get to the word --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- saying it's not censorship it --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let's get to the word in the Constitution.
It is an abridgement of the right of free speech, isn't it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: But illegal abridgement, yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it is an abridgement, isn't it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It is a possible abridgement, yes if --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Possible, is it a possible or is it an abridgement?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Sir, it depends if the words of the Consti --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did I understand it, do you say it's -- it's not certain as an abridgement if the government, state or municipal demands that somebody before they say something or show a picture, turn it over to the law to be looked at by Board?
Do you say that leaves the question of whether it's an abridgement of free speech?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I'll say, Your Honor, let's assume that that is an abridgement.
I'll say that is an abridgement of this sort.
But it depends upon whether or not the Constitution is actually --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Believes what it said?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, no.
Not in that sense, sir.
Whether or not it means unfettered, unlicensed right to speak at any times under any circumstances under any condition and say what one thinks.

But I do not think that this is the interpretation that has been put upon that provision of the Constitution down through the years that there have been some abridgements that have been recognized as legal ones, as such.
Obscenity itself if the Constitution says --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I thought that the argument there was that that really was a speech, as just kind of exploiting words.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I understand that but here again sir, is an interpretation and the clear and present danger doctrine is another interpretation that is what we're talking about.
So we say that there are some circumstances under which free speech in some condition under which it may not be unfettered as such.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How does the Board or Council -- how many are they?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: There are nine members sir and I believe at the present time, there are there alternate members.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do they elect them?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: They are appointed by the city council and they are required to have certain backgrounds in art and in literature and in philosophy and this sort of thing and some wide range of backgrounds.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Are they removable?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: They are removable, yes sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: By what?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: By the city council as such and this is the way it has actually worked.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What are their occupations?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What are their occupations?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The occupations of those that are presently serving on it are a housewife, a preacher, a public relations man, a builder in construction, a real estate individual -- one that is versed in real estate matters and real estate business, a writer, a writer and interpreter, and the generally this is the background of these individuals.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I assume then none of them have any political affiliation?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No sir, they do not for this purpose.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about the housewife?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: For this purpose.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about the housewife?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I do not know what are political affiliations are, I've never heard their expressions, because actually the Dallas system is a little different maybe and that we do not have political parties insofar as city council is concerned, it's nonpolitical in that particular respect.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You just have the ins and the outs.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The ins and outs, that's right sir.
Maybe that's political in the sense, but that's what we actually have sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: All these people serve without pay, don't they?
The members serve without pay?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Without pay, sir.
Without pay and there's quite a burden on them because when the movie submitted, it must be done within the time limit and if --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They see a lot of movies for nothing, don't they?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, they get rather tired of them Your Honor, but they do, and they take their own time and they actually see these at a time in which they are actually available to them and made so by the industry.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Just --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- a matter of interest, do they have their own projection room or something?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No sir, they do not have.
The industry has -- has made the projection room available to them and told them at what times it will be available and they make themselves available at that time.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, with the local theaters or something?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The local theater people, yes sir.

And in their viewing rooms, they have viewing rooms in Dallas in which they view movies that come in from all parts of United States for the exhibitors themselves to view to see whether or not they want to make the contracts in these sorts of things.
So this, we realize is not in every city.
Every city doesn't have these exhibitors --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Is this movie here for us to see?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir.
The movie is available as I understand it that the industry has made it available for this Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How many did you say -- how many movies did you say they had reviewed in a year?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Your Honor, they have had submitted to them 1900.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: 1925 in a two-year-period.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In a two-year-period?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So they have -- they have actually sat through 1900 of those of pictures, is that correct?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Not actually, no sir.
They have not.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, how they -- how do they pass on them if they haven't seen them?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Many times a movie is submitted as classified suitable for young persons.
These people all do research and background.
They get all of the information they can from the writers and from the reviewers throughout the country and submit these things, and then they consider this.
And if there's no doubt about it and they can see no doubt about it or no indication of it, they do not actually view the movie as such.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But they don't classify it as unsuitable without seeing it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No sir.
If they're going to classify it as unsuitable, it must either be because the industry has said we submitted as unsuitable.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Does that happen?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Your Honor, it happened in 565 out of 604 cases.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: 565 out of 1925 over two-year-period I have?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes (Voice Overlap) well, yes that is correct but of the 604 that were designated not suitable --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: 39 by the Board and 564 by the exhibitors?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Supposing a movie sets by on the scene and were upon to the members of the Board viewing on Saturday night as free, to see the movie (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Justice Harlan, you understand human nature very well, I see that because this has happened.

And when it has happened they have then gone back and asked the Board to view the movie and have told that movie industry, they're doing it, and asked them to come in and actually present any evidence they desire to do so.
May I point out that this is an open hearing at all times.

The press is always present when they're discussing these movies, that the exhibitor and the producer or anyone else is requested and asked to come in, submit any evidence they want to, and present any ideas they might have about these movies.
And we think that this is the way it should be.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are they sometimes some of these cases are settled by the distributor or exhibitor agreeing to delete certain scenes and that sort?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: We have not attempted to ask the exhibitor to delete any scene.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Had they ever offered to do that?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: If so, I'm not aware of it sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, when the distributor submits a picture or an exhibitor does as the unsuitable for young persons as you say it that happened in 565 times, do they submit it as unsuitable in terms of the classification it has had in the distributor's private organization or do they submitted as unsuitable in terms of the Dallas ordinance?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Unsuitable in the terms of the Dallas ordinance.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And they want to classify that way.
I mean they don't object to it as (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: They do not object to it, as being classified that way.
Now, I realize and let me be the first to say that counsel may say, well, this is under threat and I realize when the ordinance said there is some possibility of that and there would not.
I don't think these many would've been submitted by the industry itself if there been no ordinance search.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, of course not.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Or if that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There wouldn't have been any permission at all --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- unless there's an ordinance.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's right.
And so -- but at the same time I think it shows --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: At least in 565 times the industry said that we just don't want to litigate it.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, I think it's more than this.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: May I ask -- what?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I think it's more than this, more than just saying we don't want to litigate.
I think that actually it's also saying that we recognize that these under this ordinance are not suitable.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In terms of the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, what do they offer to --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I beg your --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If they think it's not suitable, why wouldn't they just not use them if that's here?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, there's still profit in one whether it's not suitable or whether it is suitable.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But, once they offer it to the Board and say it, “We want to show it but we recognize and come to you and tell you it's not suitable for the young persons.”
I don't understand that procedure, why they wouldn't do it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I'm sorry.
I don't understand Mr. Justice Black --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What I understand is when the exhibitors want to exhibit a picture, comes up and says, “Now, here I'm submitting to this Board, for examination, look at this picture, I myself do not think I want to offer it.
It should not be shown.”

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's a bad picture to show.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, no.
No --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But we're going to offer it to you.
Why don't they do that?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No.
Your Honor, this is not the way it works.
They submit it as not suitable and say we request permission --
