turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Not suitable for children?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Not suitable for young persons.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And we are willing to exhibit it in Dallas with the label on it in our advertising not suitable for children under the ordinance.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct.
And in the case --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And not to sell tickets to children?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct.
We have complied with the ordinance so far as this movie is concerned, and in that case, the Board itself does not actually see the movie.
The Board itself does not actually do other than to accept the classification that's put on it by the movie industry itself.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What you're saying is, isn't in that idea meeting their consideration, they would be satisfied to have this picture exhibited by -- with the statement that we don't think it's suitable for children, but that wouldn't be good to be saying -- it is going to enter into a legal agreement, somebody could be tried if a child went, is it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Your Honor, I think this -- I think if a --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the Board entered (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- the Board had acted on it which they do in those cases and had acted on it.

And then they submitted this classification and then they did allow children to come and view it without their parent or guardian or husband or wife, yes, I think under the ordinance they could be prosecuted in the corporation courts, with the fine up to $200, this is the limits of the penalty involved in the case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do they've got larger ordinances where they say not suitable for children?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: You say, are there larger ordinances?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, do they get -- do the motion picture operators get bigger crowds when they say this is not suitable for children.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice Warren, just last Saturday -- last Friday, I received the phone call that told me that this was a fact.
I do not know it to be so, that sometimes this brings in more crowds and more profit than without.
I can't -- I can't actually substantiate it one way or the other.
I would say this so, I'd say that the social opprobrium referred to by counsel does not attach to a label such as this.

It is not indirect censorship as he refers to in that particular manner and I would cite for an example, if I might, something that's well known to all of us and that is the bars where liquor is served and the fact that young people are not admitted to those, certainly does not prevent many people patronizing those bars.
We do not think that there is a social opprobrium attached to this thing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Am I wrong in thinking that there's nothing in the Constitution that protects the sale of liquor such as there is to protect freedom of speech.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I think you're right Mr. Justice Black.
I think you're right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Bickley, I gather this under 18 ordinance, municipal ordinance, that's been repealed, has it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That has been repealed, yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And replaced by this under 16?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That is correct.
Now, I know there's been a lot to do and made about that fact.

We hope that in the passage of the ordinance and in the actual application of it that we're doing everything we can to make it a sensible one and actually to balance if you will in whatever sense we have to and whatever sense we need to the right to protect the young person.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: But at the same time give --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think that the way a parent can and if he wants his child to see a picture, he's 16, he can let him see it if you go with him.
But if he doesn't go with him, it's a criminal offense?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: This is correct, Your Honor.
This is correct.
Now, --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's a criminal offense only for the exhibitor?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Only --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Not for the parent?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, only for the exhibitor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Neither the parent nor the child is --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What about the boy that goes?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: There is an offense to the individual who falsifies his age or who fraudulently -- fraudulently attempts to get in and does get in.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But of course he's 15 and he's asked to the cashier, I'm 15, the cashier says, go in and he goes in --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Then --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- the boy subject to any offense?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The boy is not subject to any (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But the exhibitor is?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The exhibitor subject to the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if the boy just walks up and buys a ticket and just sold to him no questions asked, no offense either?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, no offense in that way.
We in fact actually --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No offense if he goes to see it?
Without his father?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No.
There's no offense in that particular case unless he falsifies in order to see it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, suppose he got in -- suppose he doesn't just tell it direct falsification, but that he goes up and buys ticket, he's represented and he's old enough to go in there.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, this is a representation of a sort, yes sir, I admit that but --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And he could be charged?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Not such that -- it could -- if he could be proven yes, it be possible but actually you cannot find a juvenile of this kind any how (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Have you had any prosecutions under this one?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No prosecutions.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Of anybody?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Not of anybody.

The -- I would like to state to this Court that attempting to comply with what the law is whether we like it or not that all parties have done their utmost in trying to get the thing in such a way that actually we could present it as a law question and that we could finally come out with some rules and guidelines on this new type of concept and it is a little bit new.
Under which we can operate, protect our young people if you will, but at the same time grant to all individuals all of the First Amendment freedoms that we can and that should be granted to them.
Now, this is not an easy concept.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You haven't yet tried to censor any books that may have story like this what you say is bad in this particular picture.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No sir, we have not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) who read this?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: We have not concerned ourselves with books, we think here again -- here again and we have a state statute on it so therefore we could not even if we so desired.
The city could not, but the state could.

But we have not concerned ourselves with it because we think this goes in to the home and here again the parent has the right to take care of his own child, the same as the TV movies that were referred a minute ago.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why doesn't he have the same right to take care of his child by letting him go to a movie if he wants to without going with him?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: For this reason we think, Your Honor, and right or wrong, we think it is a valid concept that he cannot explain to his child the difference between right and wrong or the difference between morality and immorality or sexual promiscuity and smut unless he's there with him.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Oh, you expect to be that way and explain it to him as they go along?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Not as they go along, Your Honor.

Not as they go along, but in order to -- to actually fulfill his duty as a parent, we think that this is one of the things that should be required and we do not want to impinge on that right of the parent if we can keep from doing so and we hope that it's not necessary --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: How long is this ordinance when its 18-year-old one to 16-year-old one, I mean the total span, how long has it been enforced?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Approximately it was passed first in April of 1965, there's a first passage.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Did it get to referendum?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, it did not go to referendum and it was not necessary.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: How much does it cost you, how much does it cost a child to be admitted to this intellectual and emotional feast in the theatre there?
What's the admission charge?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Sir up until 12 years of age, I believe, it's 60 cents or some such thing and a dollar-and-a-half afterwards, it varies.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We'll recess now.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice Warren and Associate Justices of this Court, I would like to clear up a misstatement that I made to this Court in my argument this morning.

On page 126 of the record in the ordinance, makes it unlawful for any young person to enter or remain in the viewing room of any theater where a film classified not suitable for young person is being exhibited.
I misinformed the Court, I apologize.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So this means that a young person of 16 who happen to get in will be prosecuted?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: For what?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: He would be -- he would be prosecuted for actually violating the ordinance and that's all.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) but what -- what's the punishment?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, the only punishment that can be given to a person of that age is to turn them over to move to juvenile authorities actually.
You cannot fine him.
You cannot put him in jail.
Really there's -- it's like many of our other juvenile halls, it's rather hard to enforce actually.

It would only be one of a number of things that would have to be proven maybe in a District Court later on to show that it was a delinquent or that maybe he was not properly taken care of by his parents and this sort of thing.
But this is about all you could do in a case like that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Suppose it'd be in a nature of truancy, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Same and similar type of thing and that's about all --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- we can do, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That also provides the punishment for anyone who knowingly permits him to view it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Knowingly permits him, that is correct and knowingly is a hard proposition but it must be proven.
It would have to be --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) so suppose his father permitted him knowingly.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Without his presence, then his father would be actually the one that would be prosecuted in a situation like that.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if he will be prosecuted, what's the fine?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Does it --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Up to $200-fine.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No -- no imprisonment?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No imprisonment.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Then knowingly permit comes under Section 46 (a) (4) (a) which as I read it applies only to an exhibitor or his employee.
It should be unlawful for any exhibitor or his employee knowingly--

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- to permit any young person to view that.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That does apply to the exhibitor or his employee.
The part which applies to the father would apply to the father is over in Section (c) on page 127.
It would be a case in which he gives to a young person a ticket to go to the movie or purchase it for him and take it or some such thing as this.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I think you had there have been no prosecution of any kind under this ordinance.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, there have not, Your Honor.

The one thing I think we need to keep in mind and I reiterate to the Court is the fact that we view this as a classification ordinance and not as a censorship ordinance because there is no restraint on the content of speech as such.
The only restraint is on the audience that may actually view this content.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So, why wouldn't that be censorship if I -- if playing with words the Court took that, why wouldn't that be censorship?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: First Amendment gives the right to speak and the right to hear.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes, I understand Mr. Justice Black it does.
It also gives a right of choice and in this case, no individual is prohibited from seeing it.
The conditions are the only thing -- their conditions are the only thing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And this condition is the right to see it.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Their condition is right to see it under certain circumstances.
The same thing as we do when we talk about free speech in a parade.

A parade cannot be held at all times under all conditions when any individual, any 10,000 individuals desire to hold them because there are other freedoms and there are other rights that must be given some --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That-- it's quite a different thing, that's doing something plus free speech.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Just marching up and down.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's the difference?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Alright, may I refer to the movie theater if I might as this Court has referred to it and that's hollering fire in the movie theater in which situation, Your Honor, I think it's not unlimited free speech.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, he wouldn't have a right to go in there and disturb the people.
Nobody would.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Under the speech --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's speaking when he wants to and as he wants to and under the conditions (Voice Overlap) as I see it Your Honor and it's this -- it's this reason, I say it, this what makes hard law makes it tough and these cases are not easy, if they were.
This Court would not be having to seat on, as many as it has to, at this particular time.

But this is a time in history when I think we need to look at this type of law to see whether or not the Constitution as we know it is a document alive, if it can support a nation that not only has a past but must have a future.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you mean by that?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I mean by that simply this, Your Honor, that to strictly construe and without any fetters whatsoever, this can be the sort upon which we impale ourselves rather than the sort upon which we fight for our country.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean the judges should adopt it to meet circumstances?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I think it must under certain circumstances and in light of present day circumstances, just exactly what this Court did in the Robel case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's the purpose of the written Constitution if the Court can change it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor if we had any instrument that was not subject to interpretation --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about interpretation, interpretation in explaining what you think it means and it means when it came out?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir, I understand.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's quite a different thing --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I understand.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) to take the position, that the Court should adopt it to meet circumstances of the time even though it didn't do that as it was written.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think this -- I think that if and this is a personal opinion on my part, I think that if this is an instrument that has no latitude --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No what?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- no latitude.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- if the Court must obey as written?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No Your Honor, I say if it's an instrument that has no latitude.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's what --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: By that I mean, it has --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- if it has no latitude if it's to be construed according to its meaning --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: You're right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- but if it has no latitude, it's just there and --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- it applies, that's the way it should be amended.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And Your Honor if it's there and if it's there in unfettered terms like that then I have a right to disturb any meeting I want to at any time and under any circumstances.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you?
Why would you have a right to go into a church and disturb that meeting but the church own the church?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor under the freedom of speech, if it were an untrammeled right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's the freedom of speech where you have a right to speak.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's not -- that doesn't allow you to come in here for instance and make a speech or go into a church, you can't do that, that's not freedom of speech.
That's freedom to go where you please even though somebody else owns a property in our system.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, then under freedom of speech I'd have a right maybe to get me a megaphone and stand outside and speak into that church --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, would you?
Why wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- outside, (Voice Overlap) I say you do not have that right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why wouldn't you have that right?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I don't think I do.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And I don't think this --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I mean, if I --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: --this Court thinks I do.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- if I have to agree with you, then why wouldn't you have that right?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: But I'm saying this is because of the enlightened interpretation that's been put on the words in the Constitution.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I think it's because you follow the Constitution as it's written.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, I think maybe I'm not communicating properly with the Justice, but I think this is so, yes.
You're following it as written and as written it must have the mind of men applied to it.
And I think that's what we know.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The mind of men applied to it, to interpret it and enforce it as written but not to change it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, I don't think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why don't judges have anymore right to change it than anybody else.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Your Honor, I don't think this Court has changed it and I don't think this is --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I agree with you --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- a change of it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- not much.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Bickley --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- I have great trouble with your crying fire in the crowd at theater, I think they all agree that you can't do it.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But if somebody does cry fire, I have a right to listen to it, don't I?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Generally, (Voice Overlap), it's advisable to listen Mr. Chief -- Justice in these circumstances.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, this --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: You do have a right (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) somebody to look at something.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: You do have a right to listen to it, that's correct because --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In this case we have the right to look at the movie.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Everybody has a right to look at it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Not an unescorted child under 16.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Not an unescorted child under 16, that's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- neither does an unescorted child under 16 have a right to make many other choices.
Your Honor, may I cite one for example.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm listening.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: As this Court has held in the case of the inoculations given to the children at school even though it's against his religion.
The child has no right to make the choice.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, at this -- I don't know whether the parent could make this choice.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The parent can't even make that choice, Your Honor.
So, I'm saying that that are --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, let me see how you get that over into this case.
This case is a picture that you aren't banning, you're just restricting --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- the right of people to see it.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And it's done without any given reason at all.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Your Honor, it's correct.
They -- the Board has not given a written reason as to why.
They have done it under the confines of the ordinance.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How do I know that?
I take their word for it.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, yes in that particular situation, the same as -- as when a court quite often makes a decision without giving all of the reasons for it and none of our District Courts --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Now, let's get our answers correct.
You said without giving all of the reasons?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But in this case they didn't give any reason.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, except they said that we -- the Court actually said that he thinks we were entitled to an injunction on the law.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, I'm talking about the Board itself.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: The Board itself gave no written reason.
And the only reasons given were those that were given in the Court by two members of the Board, you're correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I have a great trouble --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And this is maybe -- this is maybe something that should be more closely drawn as you actually said in the Robel case when you're trying to decide between the validities of the two things, the legislative power on one hand and the individual rights on the other.
Maybe you draw a narrow line and maybe this is one of the lines we missed, we tried not to but it's possible.
And certainly we understand the intent of it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Bickley, I'm just wondering if it isn't -- but then the situation where neither the Board nor the Court makes any findings.

Now, I suppose you have four of your board members think that one scene in the picture takes it and the other five of it, don't think that one does but they do think another scene affects it, but they just put them together and say, “Well, it's bad”.
And then they go to the Court and the Court thinks well maybe the first one is alright, but the second one is wrong.
Now, has the Court passed on anything that we should reach?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I don't understand the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I mean --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- Mr. Chief Justice question at length --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I mean that, is there any -- is there any basis for us determining whether they acted rationally or lawfully in what they did --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Oh!
Yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- when it comes to us?
What -- what is it we act upon?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes sir, I think there is.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You mean because the Supreme Court of the state guessed from -- from what the trial court decided and the Board decided made it bad?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No, I don't think that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What does?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- Mr. Chief Justice.

But I think the thing that this Court has to act though is the evidence that was presented, the ordinance itself in the face of the Constitution and the writings of this Court that they have every opportunity on earth to determine whether or not that the ordinance itself is valid and whether it's properly drawn.

Now, as to its application to this particular movie, I would assume that this Court as it has in some other situations I understand, may would want to see the movie itself to see whether or not it was properly applied because as I understand it, you must make that final decision.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But without any findings in the courts below to support us?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I think there are findings Your Honor.
In the Court of Civil Appeals opinion, the Court was very explicit in saying what they based their decision on.
And this was a matter that went up to the Supreme Court of the State of Texas.

Supreme Court of the State of Texas in (Inaudible) would simply meant that they didn't agree with everything but they thought they reached a right conclusion and it was a upon -- it's on this record that it comes to this Court then and the final arbiter as to whether or not this movie meets the standards.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Bickley against what standard are we to test our view of this motion picture?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I think from a standard in the ordinance if the Court finds it as a constitutional standard which we think it is.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In other words, we're not going to test it against any standard of obscenity?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I don't think it is a complete obscenity question Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, --whenever.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- we have viewed motion pictures before, it has been in the context of an argument that motion picture is not obscene within the definition of obscenity that the Court has fashioned.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That is not the way we'd --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- look at this.
Well, now how can we know, what are we to take, out 47 different standards or something in this ordinance, some about Mr. Nizer said there were great number?

Are we to test to see whether it complies with anyone as we view what the standard means without your courts telling us what it means or without the Board telling us which of the several standards would apply when it --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It's possible --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- passed by this?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: It's possible Mr. Justice Brennan that the Courts were remised in this respect --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, remised but --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And it -- and I think -- what I think this Court --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But have a little sympathy for our shore --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I do have.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- well, what are we -- well, what are we going to do?
We don't know what under which this was classified, do we, because we haven't been told --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the way you put it though, there's not even a federal -- we wouldn't even be dealing with the federal question, you said once you decide the statute's constitutional, you just apply the ordinance, that is just a state law question and why we would even be concerned with it at all.
Should we really be concerned of whether the ordinance is valid on its face and if so --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- has it been constitutionally --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- derived --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- applied in this case.
Now it doesn't make --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- any difference to you, I take it, whether the Court approaches this case is saying that you may -- that perhaps the First Amendment allows the state to restrict the access of children to non-obscene matter or whether obscenity is applied to children simply has a different meaning.

Do you care -- would you care if the Court whether you call this obscenity or not you, you don't see how you would care if the Court says -- if the Court says, “Well this is an obscenity case, It's a question of --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: I would get --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- of the question of obscenity for children.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, I would hope the Court would do what it has indicated and maybe on one occasion and that is that that material that is harmful to children or that can create problems with children maybe ought to be included in the definition of obscenity.

If this is what you're talking about then I'm -- I certainly can agree with the Court if we're talking about a definition similar to obscenity for adults and with all of the requirements that it has there, I think it will not --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But this --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- meet the end that it must meet.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In this particular case as you view, you've seen this picture, it's -- it's the invitation to sexual promiscuity that makes -- that raises the question about --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- this picture?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that is in the obscenity feel, I take it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That is correct, sir.
That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, I suppose you would say -- I suppose at least partly respectable argument could be made that under the United States Constitution, a state or a municipality would be constitutionally free to say that no children under 16 could go to any movies at all say after 8 P.M. unless accompanied by their parents or could say that no children under 16 could go to movies unless accompanied by their parents that the Board had expressed an opinion about were unsuitable for children based on -- maybe the Board might say that all we want to children to see in our community are Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.
Quite without reference to obscenity is what I'm trying to say.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes, I understand.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Isn't that your real (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: What we're referring to --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- that our obscenity cases are not truly relevant to this case, isn't that what you're trying --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
That is correct, that they are not truly relevant to this problem and --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- to the thing that must be taken into consideration in this case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what are the limitations on the Board then in determining what is good for children and what isn't?
If obscenity isn't the test, obscenity as it applies to children is not the test, what test is there for the Board?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Your Honor, we have attempted to establish a test in the ordinance whether or not it's constitutional is of course a question that is --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- now being presented.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or you heard --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Could he answer that please?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh!
Excuse me.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And to determine what the test should be, we're trying to apply of the law we can muster to try to arrive at this and --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And what you have mustered, that's what I --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Well, the only thing we been able to muster at this point are the indications by this Court that this is a special problem and a legitimate interest of the state and that is the protection of its young people.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Confined within the Senate.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And then in the context -- yes, in the context of the obscenity cases for adults, then we've tried to adapt it over as best as we can and without going too far we hope in this respect.
Now, to do that is just as hard as it is to define obscenity as such and to determine what is obscenity?
We know this and for that reason maybe inaptly sometimes we have expressed it.
I cannot answer with certain definiteness the Mr. Chief Justice's question because I'm not sure that it can be answered as a definite factor.
I hope that we can get guidelines in which we can reach more definiteness.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Bickley, I -- it's like asking you so many questions -- but when you say you drew on something this Court said, are you -- do you have reference to what -- in opinion in Jacobellis said on this subject?
Is that what you think (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: We are -- we're hoping that we had properly interpreted.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, but when you said that there was something that this Court said --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes, what this Court --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- you're speaking of what was said in Jacobellis?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: In Jacobellis, yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well now, that of course was in the context of obscenity.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: That is correct.
That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But I thought you just said and answered --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- Mr. Justice Stewart that you're trying to reach for something beyond --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- the context of obscenity.

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: And we're trying to move it from the obscenity for adults over to the protection of children without doing violence to the First Amendment as best we can.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But getting beyond the obscenity area?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Your Honor, we've talked about obscenity here and if we're talking about obscenity as it can be defined so far as it concerns children and we think that this is generally what we've done in this ordinance then we have no quarrel with that.
No quarrel with that.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you think what you've generally done really is focus on obscenity in the context of exhibition to children --

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: Of exhibition --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- is that it?

turn.speaker: n_alex_bickley
turn.label: Mr. N. Alex Bickley
turn.text: -- to those below the age of 16 years.
This was the same thing that Mr. Justice Hughes in the Federal District Court and the Circuit Court in New Orleans said the due obscenity rules if applied to this statute would be proper.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Nizer?

turn.speaker: louis_nizer
turn.label: Mr. Louis Nizer
turn.text: Thank you, sir.
The standards which this ordinance sets forth have in many areas already been rejected by this Court.
It might be worth the moment to look at the standards themselves.

In determining that a picture is not suitable for children, the Board must first determine whether the picture describes or portrays brutality, criminal violence or depravity or nudity or sexual promiscuity or extramarital or abnormal sex relations.

Second, if the picture describes any of these phenomena, the Board must determine whether the portrayal is such that it is likely “to insight or encourage” crime or delinquency or actual promiscuity in the part of the young persons.

Third, in determining whether it is likely to insight or encourage crime, delinquency and so on, the Board must determine whether there is in its judgment “a substantial probability that it will create an impression on young persons that such conduct is profitable, desirable, acceptable, respectable, trustworthy and commonly accepted.”
Now, identical of similar standards have been condemned by this Court and other courts as too vague to satisfy constitutional guarantees.

For example, “sexual immorality” People against Bookcase; “prejudicial to the best interest of the people”, the Gelling case; “Creating a harmful impression on the minds of children”, Paramount against Chicago stricken out; “Sexual immorality is desirable, acceptable, or improper patterns of behavior”, Kingsley stricken out, and some of these cases of course have dealt with the protection of children.
That doctrine that there may be variable obscenity has never been extended to mean that there can be variable vagueness and this statute is void and defective completely because of vagueness.
Just two or three other brief points, it has been suggested here for the first time that my client United Artist may protest and has standing before this Court.

That is not so at page 128 of the record without reading it subdivision 7, only in exhibitor may file a notice of nonacceptance, not a distributor and indeed the exhibitors as this Court has observed takes little to deter the exhibitor from going to this kind of a contest and that one occasion we've even had to threaten to sue the exhibitors so we've filed as nonacceptance so we could get an intervening application.
Second, with respect to the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Nizer, to what extent had distributors participated and submit in these voluntary submissions?

turn.speaker: louis_nizer
turn.label: Mr. Louis Nizer
turn.text: None at all.
And we have protested against them in many instances and we have no standing before the Board.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you know how often the -- how often the -- let's say in the 565 submissions that unsuitable, how often those 565 correspondent with the distributor's classification of their own (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: louis_nizer
turn.label: Mr. Louis Nizer
turn.text: In very few, if any though I have not the statistics before me but I will go further Mr. Justice White.
The exhibitor has yielded against his will in these matters.
There is this matter of fighting the authorities of a community in which you live and depend upon the good will of it and this very existence of this ordinance is itself a suppression.

There would not have been 39 overrulings in the exhibitors who's finally saying this is alright with me when he submits a specific request for a suitable classification and it's overruled, and he says let's go along because he doesn't want to spend the money for counsel to come up here.
One other observation about the Freedman case which I think we owe to Your Honor, a candid statement about it.

We don't think that the Freedman case has been complied within consequently, this statute is void in any event in this application to the reasons I have given that you can have a complete final determination without any judicial participation here.

But I would -- I think we owe to this Court to be candid to say that the motion picture industry has never been able to adjust itself to the proposition that while other medias such as magazines, newspapers, television even comic books may not be restrained by prior consideration, prior submission that we cannot share that sunshine and that we stand in the shadow of a five to four decision which says that we alone, the motion picture industry comes into a special category.
We would therefore respectfully suggest now that this has demonstrated the ineffectualness of the Freedman case in attempting to modify the effects of the Times case that if we went on the cause --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Excuse me, the Freedman was not five to four.
Maybe it was seven --

turn.speaker: louis_nizer
turn.label: Mr. Louis Nizer
turn.text: No, the Times case was five to four.
That's the one that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The Freedman is the one that's settled, isn't it?
The proposition that there are distinctions which justify the measure of prior restraints with Freedman sanction --

turn.speaker: louis_nizer
turn.label: Mr. Louis Nizer
turn.text: I think it was --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That -- that was not a five to four decision.

turn.speaker: louis_nizer
turn.label: Mr. Louis Nizer
turn.text: No, not that.

The Times case which puts the motion picture industry in the special category was and I merely observed that I think while the Freedman case was an admirable effort to avoid the abuse by these judicial requirements that nevertheless it hasn't worked.

Well, here we are on Viva Maria, if Your Honor if you see that picture you'll be shock that this picture could be caught in that kind of a net when it was intended for something else and next day it will be something else and then it will be as I've indicated a proliferation of these ordinances.

I wish to observe that while it is true that in this case there's no salary to these people, that in most of these proposals, they not only receives salaries but there is a fee for submitting the picture for their examination and you get the entire bureaucracy imposed upon this.

And I think that this will cause a great flood of this kind of case whereas if we -- if in dealing with this difficult question, if we subjected the restraint to at least to penal provisions or at most injunction and declaratory judgment with all the safeguards for a defendant with the presumption of innocence and beyond the reasonable doubt, then I think this perhaps might be held in control.
And the penal statute would get after the man that should get after some case where somebody is really trying to overstep the bounds of sensibilities of the American people.
This is not this case at all.
It doesn't even come up on obscenity.
